Having a basic understanding of how different algorithms work, such as linear regression, support vector machines, and artificial neural networks, is essential for understanding how machine learning works. So let me give you some examples of where and how machine learning works. It will bring you more clarity. Machine learning is just finding pattern in the data. Nothing more, nothing less. Consider this image. On the X-axis is the ‘ age ’ which starts from about ‘20’ and goes till ‘70’. On the Y-axis is ‘ Salary ’ which ranges from 0 to 2,00,000. Can you identify the trend / pattern in the data. In anyway is ‘ Salary ’ getting influenced by ‘ age ’? What do you think? Take some time, pause and answer. Let me give one more image for the similar analysis. See below. Now can you guess if by any means, ‘Salary’ depends on the value of ‘Experience Years’? So in both the images/data there was a trend or pattern . In first image, we see that as age increases salary is also increasing but not all points follow this pattern. In second image, this pattern is quite clear and we can clearly see the trend which seems quite linear . Can we guess the expected salary from this data? Suppose if experience is 5 years, what could be salary? Using your intuition you might think it must be above 60,000 and less than 70,000. So wee see finding pattern in data is not more than analyzing the data and inferring from the various graphs/plots. But what when we have more complex data like this. And suppose you have data around 2,00,000 records. You can’t plot data which has more than 2 columns. And it become difficult to manually analyze what’s going on under the hood. So we need some techniques which are capable enough of finding the pattern on it’s own . So what does any machine learning algorithm do ? It’s a technique which can directly find the pattern in data if any, without you being getting involved. In this data, using statistical techniques like polynomial regression we can get a equation like above. We just provide the data . And the statistical modelling techniques used here(polynomial regression) can find the trend . This is really powerful. Now you don’t have to manually analyse each data set. Even you do you can’t generate mathematical equations. Some sophisticated techniques is doing that. But what if you don’t understand the techniques/Mathematics used for it. See, that will really matter if you are working for very complex problems. Most of us really don’t necessarily need to know the Math . But we need to clearly understand what’s it is doing. If you can understand what I explained, you can certainly learn machine learning/statistical modelling. Let me give one more example. Can you find out the equation here? Seems impossible. No worries. Let machine learning find it for you. That’s the power of it and hence it is used so widely. Do you know what kind of equation will represents this line which in turn represents the trend in the data which is quite linear. This much Math is expected from you. If you are understanding these terms, you can start learning machine learning. Definitely we have more advanced techniques in ML which are much harder to understand and it’s take lot of time and efforts and patience ( most important ) to learn all of it. So definitely knowing more and more mathematics will help. For sure. But not all applications need to use all advanced techniques. The more you learn, you will solve more complex problems. You need to master Mathematics / techniques from ground up/ scratch to become expert in machine learning. If you use only Python / R libraries surely it works, but not in bringing more accuracy to your models beyond a certain value. For more accurate ML models that you need to play with machine learning and hence you need to know math behind it. So remember, analytical skills and learning each machine learning techniques is the only way. Practice and see what you need to improve. Let me give one more technique( Segmentation / Classification ) widely used. Here Purchased is the column in which we are interested. We want to find if it is a outcome of other columns like Gender, Age or Salary. TRY TO FIND THE PATTERN YOURSELF! You can see that whenever purchased is ‘0’ i.e ‘not purchased’ it is always due to less age. And ‘1’ i.e ‘purchased’ is when age is above 40. But again manually going through the data is not always helpful and we can employ SVM / Logistic Regression or Decision Trees to solve these kind of problems. What almost all algorithm relies on is-’ Similar input data produces similar output ’. For example in above example by analyzing the data we find people making the purchase on higher end of the age . This is also known as segmentation where we divide our data into multiple segments( regions / area ). Above we divide our data into 2 segments. One doing the purchase( over 40 age) and other not purchasing( under 40 age). We did it manually (our self) but in larger/complex data we use machine learning techniques. So the point I am making is first understand where machine learning is used and why. Even you don’t know the internals still you can use it to solve complicated problems. So machine learning has lots of theoretical concepts. Do that and solve real world example( PRACTICE ON KAGGLE/HACKER-RANK ). You can’t master all the Mathematics in one shot. So learn one technique and solve practical problems. Iterate again and again. When I started learning machine learning or Coursera I find it really tough/hard. But I did implemented two or more machine learning algorithms on my own uisng MATLAB but later moved to R as I didn’t get time to learn every algorithms in too detail. I know the math behind almost all algorithm but not implemented all from scratch . But still I am pretty useful in my previous/current company where I implemented/implementing NLP (Natural language processing) based solutions and using machine learning techniques a lot in Python . It took me almost 2 to 3 years to master machine learning. Just put more time. The more hands on you become with it, you will understand it much better. Hope it helps. Step 1: Build a strong base in statistics and mathematics Theoretically, ML has many overlaps with predictive statistics. In fact, a distinct feature of ML is that it typically deals with big data, but the techniques applied to the data all have their roots in predictive statistics. However, you cannot directly start learning these models without first understanding descriptive and inferential statistics. So you should begin by brushing up on your basic statistical concepts like mean, median, mode, etc., and the different types of graphs and charts. The next thing would be to move on to concepts of inferential statistics. Some of the most important things to learn here for ML would be the different probability distributions, hypothesis testing, chi-square tests, ANOVA, etc. In this way, you can gradually enter into predictive statistics, like regression analysis, time series forecasting, etc. These are the methods that will form the foundation for elementary ML concepts like CART (classification and regression trees), validation techniques, clustering, discriminant analysis, artificial neural networks, etc. This covers the prerequisites for learning ML from a conceptual point of view.
